unnormalised: The auto-rickshaw sputtered to a halt, its meter stubbornly displaying ₹250. "Bhaiya, petrol khatam," the driver, a wiry man named Raju, announced with a sheepish grin. "Will need to fill up about 2 liters." I sighed. This was the third time this week. The price of petrol had been creeping up steadily; last I checked it was ₹105.45 per litre at the Indian Oil pump near my house.
normalised: The auto-rickshaw sputtered to a halt, its meter stubbornly displaying rupee two hundred and fifty. "Bhaiya, petrol khatam," the driver, a wiry man named Raju, announced with a sheepish grin. "Will need to fill up about two liters." I sighed. This was the third time this week. The price of petrol had been creeping up steadily; last I checked it was rupee one hundred and five point four five per liter at the Indian Oil pump near my house.

unnormalised: Raju pushed the auto to the side of the road, a familiar routine for him, I imagined. He pulled out a plastic bottle – the kind that used to hold 750 ml of cola – and gestured towards a nearby petrol bunk. "Bas 10 minute, Saab," he promised. As he walked off, I thought about how much these small costs added up for someone like Raju, who probably made a meager Rs. 500 a day.

As he walked off, I thought about how much these small costs added up for someone like Raju, who probably made a meager rupees five hundred a day.

unnormalised: I idly checked my phone. My car, a Maruti Suzuki Alto, had been giving me trouble lately too. The mileage had dropped from 20 kmpl to a disappointing 15 kmpl. A mechanic had suggested an engine tune-up, costing around Rs. 2000, but I’d been putting it off.

unnormalised: Raju returned, bottle filled to the brim. He poured the fuel into the auto's tank, a cloud of petrol fumes hanging in the air. After a few tries, the engine coughed back to life. "Hogaya, Saab," he said, wiping his brow. "This will get us another 25 km, maybe."

unnormalised: The ride continued, a bumpy reminder of the daily struggles faced by millions. I paid Raju ₹300, a little extra to cover the petrol. He smiled, a flash of white teeth in the sun. "Dhanyavad, Saab. Appka din shubh ho!" As I stepped out, I couldn't help but feel a pang of guilt for the ease with which I could afford the rising fuel costs, while Raju fought to earn every rupee.
